I can't comprehend why some continue to parrot the aspersions made against Ms. Knox and Mr. Sollecito by an abusive prosecutor and pandering media. For those who care to do the research, there exists a comprehensive and meticulous debunking of the astonishingly slipshod case against the pair -- I should say rather cases (pl.), since the prosecutor has changed his "theory," his "witnesses," and his "evidence" as often as the wind shifts. Apart from the high stakes, it would be _laughable_. The critiques are based on courtroom transcripts, witness and expert testimony, physical evidence, lab results and photographs taken by police themselves; these original materials are extensively reproduced and examined online. The cast of characters on the prosecution side includes many of the same career miscreants who were censured and/or convicted of crimes for their incompetence and malfeasance in another Italian juridical atrocity, the "Monster of Florence" serial killer case (from 1968 on), which produced 16 murder victims, a succession of bizarre and unfounded theories, convictions, and later acquittals, of innocent people. After decades of investigations and trials, nobody has been held responsible, and despite the fact that at least two book authors have independently made plausible cases and named the same suspect, the alleged perpetrator has never even been charged. This broken and corrupt system is why Meredith and countless others have not had and will never get justice.

Instructors can teach 300 person classes because there are an army of teaching assistants assigned to each of those classes. A typical TA has between 7-10 students and they are responsible for grading and hand-holding.

If you want larger classes, the instructors need to have additional support staff that is qualified to shoulder grading and hand-holding. And when that is factored in, the savings disappear.
Teaching high school is very different from college. In high school they have this thing called classroom management.

Florida's class size amendment has just such a sliding class size scale.  However, despite the public voting for it (several times), the state has found all sorts of ways to get around the constitution...fines which cost less than breaking the law, re-classifying which classes "count" under class size, etc.  Such behavior makes it very difficult to assess whether the system is working.

I am a 51 year-old northeastern Pennsylvania resident who matriculated through the K-12 public school system. My oldest daughter graduated from Penn State University with a major in Elementary Education (K -6). She currently is employed in a preschool where her class size is 10 students.

I agree that student-to-teacher ratios at public school, say K-6, should be as small as budgetary constraints allow. However I believe in a step system where the ratio of class size should increase per teacher from grades 7-9, and then increase student-to-teacher ratios again from grades 10 -12.

If a 12 grade public school teacher is complaining that 28 students is too much to handle, what is it the happens when the student must take English/Literature 101 with "300" students in the Penn State,State College, main campus auditorium in 3 months? Otherwise stated, how can a student graduate in June of his/her senior year and then be expected to learn anything in his/her freshman year where the class size has increased more than 9 fold?

Finally, I have taught (adjunct professor) only 2 business classes (Marketing 101 and Management 101), and my performance was based only on student evaluations. I think this would be a great idea for 11-12 students to evaluate many of the teachers they had during the prior 2 years. I feel strongly that student public school teacher assessment should be at least 25% of the teacher's complete evaluation.

My son has been to both private and public schools in Seattle, and I would say class size does make a difference in how engaged kids are and how much teacher interaction they get.  We will have true "education reform" when public schools can spend as much as private schools do per pupil.

Our Los Angeles high school has AP classes with 50 students, and honors and general classes with slightly fewer. In these classes, some students must sit on the floor or at lab benches, not because the school lacks chairs, but because the room cannot hold a sufficient number of desks and chairs. Large class sizes mean more administrative work for the teacher, not to mention discipline and monitoring issues, even in the high level classes. Class sizes do matter, and the effects are cumulative. The best students will always succeed, but for those who are shy, or less motivated, or who struggle academically, or who have different learning styles, large classes simply make things harder for both students and teachers.

I dare Arne Duncan, Mr. Bloomburg and Mr. Gates to teach in several classes  of 34 AP students per day. Yet, this is what is expected in many school systems in my state.  I realize those three gentlemen are not educators, but surely they can understand how difficult it is for any human being to make sure all students receive the attention they deserve.   Excellent teachers are everywhere, but why do you want to punish them with huge classes.  If I remember correctly, in college, those huge classes were the ones I learned the least.

I agree 100%. But what is your suggestion to solve this? I would propose tariffs to meant to equalize the cost of goods under conditions of great external costs. This would encourage the manufacturers to spend the money with their workers, on environmental preservation, etc. It would also raise the price of imported goods, so unskilled US and Canadian workers could compete on a more equal footing with other countries. So far, by internalizing these costs through our burdensome regulations, we have only succeeded in killing manufacturing in the US and shipping jobs overseas -- we have not actually made workers safer here -- we have made them non-workers (unemployed). Safer, but not very happy or productive.

It would be hard to keep the tariffs in line with reality, and it would be difficult from them becoming institutionalized -- but once the other countries have built the regulatory infrastructure we have, the tariffs, in theory, would gradually be reduced to zero.

It would be difficult, but what other answers to address the problem of externalities?

Corporations are masters of externalizing costs and use all manner of sophistic mumbo-jumbo to justify it.

But in every case all that is necessary to determine who should pay these costs is to look at the enormous profits corporations make. Billions. While off-shore workers who make the goods they sell are paid a dollar or so, give or take, a day.

When "all" that the corporations kill is the atmosphere, the rivers, the soil, or the bees, concerned analysts get to wag their heads and weigh the pros and cons of corporations' sophistries.

But when hundreds of workers die in a fire or a building collapse or some other immediate and undeniable consequence of corporate greed and you've got a pile of bodies staring you in the face, there is no way to deny that this one-sided game has gone too far.

Whatever the cost has ultimately got to be to provide safe working conditions and a living wage for off-shore workers, there is one and only one place to find those dollars: the profits of the brands that are only too happy to claim that subcontractors' of subcontractors behavior is none of their business.

If I profit from my suppliers' crimes, those crimes most certainly are my business.

A few questions.

1) How are "a huge inconvenience" and "inability to survive" the same thing?

2) How is having two buttons on the toilet so that you can have two different kinds of flushes better than having a toilet that flushes in one way but adequately for every occasion?

3) What is the advantage of having halls that go dark once you pass a motion sensor?

4) If American public bathrooms feature soap dispensers, as they have for at least decades, does that mean that the purpose of builders and owners was to avoid "millions of small plastic bottles winding up in the landfill every year"? Also, what difference does it make whether "millions of small plastic bottles [wind] up in the landfill every year"? Will they be sad?

5) Why is it a bad thing on a 101-degree day for a 92-year-old who has paid for a hotel room to leave the air conditioner on so that the room will be cool when he returns? Is key-card-controlled power an innovation voluntarily accepted by European hotels in order to either better satisfy customers and/or to save on their own expenses; or has the restriction been imposed on the hotels by government force? What about the other restrictions Pogue mentions?

6) What is the difference between measures designed to solve the problems of specific businesses and customers from measures designed to solve so-called "whole-world problems"? If I eat in a restaurant, am I satisfying my own hunger for my own sake, or am I thereby addressing a "whole-world problem"?

We should know what different levels of health insurance and of health care will do. Our population has plenty of these differences whose effects should be measured and known before we design or modify health programs. But we do not spend enough money on this, so we cannot design health programs on an understanding of what is happening. Instead we basically design our health care programs on hunches and lobbying. This suits the lobbyists because it keeps power in their hands rather than in the hands of the facts themselves (as chosen and interpreted by the scientific and medical communities).

Designing a health care program, or modifying it, should be a technical matter. We would decide what results we wanted and how much we were willing to pay, and technicians would give us a range of possibilities and costs. This is how we repair houses and cars. We are so far from being able to do this with health care that we lose sight that this is what we should be doing.

I have always found precise language to be a great aid to precise thinking.

We are not really talking about "unburnable carbon". Whether or not a particular carbon compound or its allotropes are combustible or not is a function of its chemical composition, particularly whether or not all its carbon atoms are already bound to oxygen atoms.

We are talking about "proscribed carbon".

This is carbon which the controlling government has ruled may not be burned because its combustion is perceived as harmful to the public good.

Anyone who reads Dot Earth knows that this perception is not universally held.

Recall that goverments derive their just powers from the consent of the governed.

Recall the most egregious time that maxim was ignored here in the US, when Prohibition turned us into a nation of scofflaws.

Imbibing alcohol is an option. Warmth, light, clean running water, clean food and reliable transport are not.

So any government which proscribes the combustion of the carbon compounds we use to obtain that warmth, light and transport had better either a) have a complete portfolio of replacement non-carbon energy sources available to all its citizens on day one, or b) resign itself to open defiance of the law, armed insurrection and the rise of massive criminal organizations made rich by smuggling needed fuel to cold, hungry, stranded citizens.

>>>"Considered as a whole, Europe's most representative mind was probably that of Blaise Pascal: at once scientific and religious, mathematical and verbal,"

The adverb "at once" is ill-chosen (whether in the sense of "simultaneously" or that of "in the same manner or to the same degree."

Pascal did almost all his mathematical work in his teens and 20s, and his literary and philosophical work in his 30s.

Along with Pierre Fermat, Pascal was the last of the talented amateurs in mathematics. The next generation of mathematicians, such as Newton and Leibnitz,, were not only professionals, but made deeper and more comprehensive contributions. Pascal made forays here and there in mathematics. His literary work however was more sustained.

Whether he was most representative of the first half of the 17th century is very debatable. Rene Descartes, in my view, made greater contributions in both mathematics (analytic geometry) and philosophy. Granted he couldn't write as beautifully as Pascal.
